description.narrative: UNICEF launched “Strengthening Urban Health Systems for Comprehensive Primary Health Care (PHC) for the Most Deprived Women and Children” with support from SIDA from 1st August 2019 to 31st August 2023. The project aimed to develop a sustainable urban PHC model for quality health services, especially for the poorest and most vulnerable urban population. The novel COVID-19 pandemic has created global havoc. Bangladesh had its first COVID-19 case on 8 March 2020. UNICEF was actively engaged in developing and revising the national COVID-19 response plan which is called BPRP (Bangladesh Preparedness and Response Plan), in collaboration with sister UN agencies and the wider development partner agencies. UNICEF also leveraged its financial and technical support through different pillar groups and technical committees formed by the DGHS as part of the COVID-19 response. Due to emergency response, to combat COVID-19 outbreak in the country, UNICEF postponed non-critical routine activities and reprogrammed some resources to support the emergency response of the MOHFW (BPRP). Against this backdrop, many of the planned project activities were either reprogrammed or re-purposed and some of the activities were postponed or deferred and most of the staff along with available resources were diverted to support the on-going COVID-19 Response Plan of the MOHFW. The on-going pandemic has also led to delayed execution of some of the activities planned for quarter 1 and 2. Amid the pandemic context, UNICEF - in consultation with the donor - carefully reviewed the activities of this project and re-programmed some of the non-essential activities to support the COVID-19 Response Plan. Despite of the COVID 19 outbreak the project has achieved several results which are stated below. UNICEF organized an assessment of urban health governance structure, existing policy and strategy framework, stakeholders mapping, existing service availability and health care seeking behaviour and vulnerability profile of population analysis. This assessment will inform the project’s focus for the urban primary health care strengthening and final report is expected by October 2020, delayed by 6 months due to difficulty in data collection amid the COVID-19 situation. However, the initial report by the consultants gave an assessment of urban health governance structure based on desk review. A roadmap was developed for strengthening existing Government led DHIS2 based Health Management Information Systems (HMIS), integrating NGO and private sector HMIS with national health information system and shared with Director MIS and Director Hospital Service Management of DGHS. Additional technical assistance was provided to the HMIS unit of DGHS to implement the roadmap for urban HMIS and to support both the routine and COVID-19 pandemic related HMIS data since the 15th of April 2020in the urban city-corporations and municipalities. One of the major achievements during the reporting period was the development of the draft urban PHC service delivery model - particularly targeting the vulnerable population in urban slums and non-slum areas. The draft PHC model was developed through a consultative process, which engaged all the stakeholders - including the urban Health Experts, Academia, Government Officials of different Ministries, urban health partners and NGO Service Managers. The model is now under review by the MOHFW for its finalization and implementation through a sustainable system approach - engaging MOHFW, MOLGRD, LGIs, DGHS and other partners. Although the model was supposed to be implemented during the 2nd quarter of this year it was delayed due to the ongoing pandemic situation. The baseline census of 40,000 HH was initiated in February 2020. The interventions to improve access to quality essential maternal, infant and young child nutrition and maternal and child health services among working women at the selected ready-made garment (RMG) factories implementing Mothers@Work programme has been focusing on building capacity of the RMG stakeholders during this reporting period. Capacity building materials have been prepared; however, the orientation and training of the stakeholders in the selected factories had been rescheduled to Q4 of 2020, due to the closure of the factories amid the COVID-19 pandemic. CoVID 19 related activities Sweden repurposed budget for CoVid 19 was primarily for Infection Prevention Control related supplies and activities. Funds were used for the procurement of the Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), following an urgent request from the MOHFW amid the shortage of PPE supplies to the facilities for the protection of the frontline health workers during the initial period of COVID-19 response. UNICEF responded promptly to the MOHFW’s urgent request of PPEs and other logistics through its global procurement services. Additional funds were availed principally for ‘Risk Communication and Community Engagement’ as a nation-wide initiative with attention to the Urban Areas. IEC material, Public Service Announcements and other communication materials were developed. It also supported the Risk Communication component of the Government’s COVID-19 response plan, District Information Officers were involved in the dissemination of the messages on preventive measures including personal hygiene and protection, social distancing of general people, and reaching vulnerable groups. In addition, these messages were broadcasted through the social media platform and television channels in the form of infographic and animation videos on benefits of staying home, adolescent nutrition and maternal nutrition. About 3.6 million people were reached.

Primärvården avser nå: 1. 45 942 gravida kvinnor för vård vid graviditet och efter förlossning samt förlossningar på vårdinrättning av 32 816 kvinnor 2. 45.942 mödrar till nyfödda får grundläggande vård, 3. 45 492 mödrar får rådgivning om nutrition för mödrar, nyfödda och små barn 4. Vaccinationsprogram till 58 123 barn, genom spårning och kartläggning 5. 20 000 hushåll, ca 100 000 personer, kommer att informeras och uppmuntras att anmäla sig till ett system för grupphälsoförsäkring. 6. 12 000 textilarbetare ska nås av Mother @ Works programmet för att förbättra deras hälso- och näringsstatus samt immunisering. 7. Projektet kommer att bygga upp kapacitet för totalt 540 anställda från nationella till operativa nivåer: (nationella politiska beslutsfattare, hälsovårdsansvariga, leverantörer av hälsovård, sjukvårdspersonal, statsanställda inom vården, kommunala institutioner, icke-statliga organisationer och privat sektor).
Detta ska att uppnås genom en kombination och en balans mellan politisk dialog och påverkansarbete samt utformning av och implementering av vårdprogram.
Primärhälsovården kommer att stärkas genom införandet av ett system för finansiell riskskydd för förbättrad användning och täckning av hälsovård för kvinnor och barn inom utsatta grupper, särskilt de som bor i slumområden. Detta ska bidra till att förbättra efterfrågan, tillgång och användning av kvalitetsservice av mödra- och neonatalvård i marginaliserade områden, och i slutändan uppfylla deras rättigheter till hälsovård och överlevnad. Detta kommer att leda till att en innovativ modell för hållbar service utformas för att förbättra tillgången till och utnyttjandet av primärhälsovård inklusive standardminimipaket för nutrition, särskilt för den fattigaste och mest marginaliserade befolkningen;
En ekonomisk skyddsmekanism genom en grupphälsoförsäkring för låginkomsttagare och socialt segregerade grupper förväntas ge möjlighet till primärhälsovård av kvalitet nära bostaden. I slutändan kommer dessa utsatta och socialt segregerade grupper att ha färre ekonomiska hinder för tillgång till livräddande primärhälsovård; Detta kommer att leda till det förväntade mål 3: Förbättrad täckning av primärhälsovård i tätbebyggelse och för socialt segregerade grupper;
En effektiv policydialog baserad på god praxis och lärdomar från projekt, innovationer och följeforskning, förväntas bidra till engagemang och samordning mellan olika sektorer och avdelningar för en urban primärhälsovård i Bangladesh.
Ett förbättrat styrsystem för urbana hälsoprogram förväntas bidra till att förbättra samordningen, mäta framsteg och ansvarsskyldighet för urban primärvård av de främsta intressenterna, nämligen ministeriet för kommunala frågor, hälsovårdsministeriet och kommunala institutioner. I slutändan kommer stadsbefolkningen, särskilt från marginaliserad områden, bli medvetna om sina rättigheter till hälsovård och välbefinnande.

The overall vision of success for this project is that by 2023, sustainable improvement in the health status of the Bangladeshi population in urban areas is achieved, particularly for the poorest and most vulnerable groups. This will encompass strengthening institutional governance for sustainable delivery of Primary Health Care for women and children amongst the vulnerable population in underserved areas, particularly in urban slums and newly included wards in city corporations and municipalities. The four expected outcomes are: 1. Health systems are strengthened through institutional reform with a functioning institutional structure and data management systems to improve accountability for delivery of efficient Primary Health Care (PHC);2. Innovative model of sustainable service delivery system is established to improve access to and utilization of PHC services especially by the poorest and vulnerable/segregated population ;3. Coverage of primary health care is improved in urban slum settlements and for socially segregated groups4. Evidence based on good practices and lessons learned is available for policy dialogue and advocacy to influence decision making processes

description.narrative: UNICEF launched “Strengthening Urban Health Systems for Comprehensive Primary Health Care (PHC) for the Most Deprived Women and Children” with support from SIDA from 1st August 2019 to 31st August 2023. The project aimed to develop a sustainable urban PHC model for quality health services, especially for the poorest and most vulnerable urban population. The novel COVID-19 pandemic has created global havoc. Bangladesh had its first COVID-19 case on 8 March 2020. UNICEF was actively engaged in developing and revising the national COVID-19 response plan which is called BPRP (Bangladesh Preparedness and Response Plan), in collaboration with sister UN agencies and the wider development partner agencies. UNICEF also leveraged its financial and technical support through different pillar groups and technical committees formed by the DGHS as part of the COVID-19 response. Due to emergency response, to combat COVID-19 outbreak in the country, UNICEF postponed non-critical routine activities and reprogrammed some resources to support the emergency response of the MOHFW (BPRP). Against this backdrop, many of the planned project activities were either reprogrammed or re-purposed and some of the activities were postponed or deferred and most of the staff along with available resources were diverted to support the on-going COVID-19 Response Plan of the MOHFW. The on-going pandemic has also led to delayed execution of some of the activities planned for quarter 1 and 2. Amid the pandemic context, UNICEF - in consultation with the donor - carefully reviewed the activities of this project and re-programmed some of the non-essential activities to support the COVID-19 Response Plan. Despite of the COVID 19 outbreak the project has achieved several results which are stated below. UNICEF organized an assessment of urban health governance structure, existing policy and strategy framework, stakeholders mapping, existing service availability and health care seeking behaviour and vulnerability profile of population analysis. This assessment will inform the project’s focus for the urban primary health care strengthening and final report is expected by October 2020, delayed by 6 months due to difficulty in data collection amid the COVID-19 situation. However, the initial report by the consultants gave an assessment of urban health governance structure based on desk review. A roadmap was developed for strengthening existing Government led DHIS2 based Health Management Information Systems (HMIS), integrating NGO and private sector HMIS with national health information system and shared with Director MIS and Director Hospital Service Management of DGHS. Additional technical assistance was provided to the HMIS unit of DGHS to implement the roadmap for urban HMIS and to support both the routine and COVID-19 pandemic related HMIS data since the 15th of April 2020in the urban city-corporations and municipalities. One of the major achievements during the reporting period was the development of the draft urban PHC service delivery model - particularly targeting the vulnerable population in urban slums and non-slum areas. The draft PHC model was developed through a consultative process, which engaged all the stakeholders - including the urban Health Experts, Academia, Government Officials of different Ministries, urban health partners and NGO Service Managers. The model is now under review by the MOHFW for its finalization and implementation through a sustainable system approach - engaging MOHFW, MOLGRD, LGIs, DGHS and other partners. Although the model was supposed to be implemented during the 2nd quarter of this year it was delayed due to the ongoing pandemic situation. The baseline census of 40,000 HH was initiated in February 2020. The interventions to improve access to quality essential maternal, infant and young child nutrition and maternal and child health services among working women at the selected ready-made garment (RMG) factories implementing Mothers@Work programme has been focusing on building capacity of the RMG stakeholders during this reporting period. Capacity building materials have been prepared; however, the orientation and training of the stakeholders in the selected factories had been rescheduled to Q4 of 2020, due to the closure of the factories amid the COVID-19 pandemic. CoVID 19 related activities Sweden repurposed budget for CoVid 19 was primarily for Infection Prevention Control related supplies and activities. Funds were used for the procurement of the Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), following an urgent request from the MOHFW amid the shortage of PPE supplies to the facilities for the protection of the frontline health workers during the initial period of COVID-19 response. UNICEF responded promptly to the MOHFW’s urgent request of PPEs and other logistics through its global procurement services. Additional funds were availed principally for ‘Risk Communication and Community Engagement’ as a nation-wide initiative with attention to the Urban Areas. IEC material, Public Service Announcements and other communication materials were developed. It also supported the Risk Communication component of the Government’s COVID-19 response plan, District Information Officers were involved in the dissemination of the messages on preventive measures including personal hygiene and protection, social distancing of general people, and reaching vulnerable groups. In addition, these messages were broadcasted through the social media platform and television channels in the form of infographic and animation videos on benefits of staying home, adolescent nutrition and maternal nutrition. About 3.6 million people were reached.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Detta projekt syftar till att lyfta några av Bangladeshs fattigaste kvinnor, som lever på landsbygden i delar av landet som är särskilt utsatta för klimatförändringarnas negativa effekter, ut ur extrem fattigdom genom att dra nytta av produktiva inkomstmöjligheter. Den primära målgruppen är 3600 kvinnor i Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha och Jamalpur distrikten även om betydligt fler människor, inklusive dessa kvinnors barn, kommer att dra viss nytta av projektets positiva effekter.
SWAPNO-II syftar till att öka målgruppens inkomster och tillgångar genom att vidga deras valmöjligheter, öka deras kapacitet att göra val, stärka deras motståndskraft mot externa chocker, inklusive klimatrelaterade katastrofer och öka deras tillgång till finansiella tjänster samt se till att projektets fördelar kvarstår över tid.
Målen ska nås genom en kombination av ansträngningar. Kvinnorna anställs först i offentliga arbeten fora att återuppbygga eller klimatsäkra kritisk infrastruktur och för det arbetet får det en liten, men säker lön var fjortonde dag under ett halvår. En del av lönen sparas automatiskt och den delen får kvinnorna tillgång till som en större engångssumma vid anställningsperiodens slut. Meningen är att den ska möjliggöra för kvinnorna att starta sina egna småföretag. Kvinnorna får också utbildning i olika vardagskunskaper och lite yrkeskunskaper som är relevanta för att hitta anställning eller starta eget företag vilket ökar deras nätverk och personliga värdighet. Stöd ges också för tillgång till digitala finansiella tjänster och försäkringar. Idén är att kvinnornas ökade inkomster, kombinerat med ökade kunskaper och självsäkerhet ska hjälpa dem att investera på ett produktivt sätt som ger dem avkastning under kommande år. Dessutom bidar projektet till att öka de lokala myndigheternas kapacitet att implementera fattigdomsreducerande och genderkänsliga sociala transfereringssystem.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This project aims at sustainably lifting some of Bangladesh’s poorest women, living in rural areas prone to the negative effects of climate change, of out of extreme poverty, primarily by making use of productive income-generating opportunities. The main beneficiaries are 3600 women in the districts of Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha and Jamalpur even if a substantially larger number of people, including these women’s children, will benefit, to various extents, from the positive effects of this project.
SWAPNO-II aims to increase the targeted women’s income and assets by expanding their choices, enhance their capabilities for exercising choices, strengthen their resilience to shocks, including disasters and climate change, and enhance their financial inclusion and ensure that the benefits are sustainable over time.
This will be achieved through a combination of efforts. The women will first be engaged in public-works to rehabilitate and/or climate proof critical local infrastructure for which they receive a small, predictable, fortnightly, salary during a period of six months. A part of the remuneration is set aside in compulsory savings which the women will access as a lump-sum at the end of the public-works period to allow them to, for example start their own small-scale businesses. They will also be trained in various life-skills as well as skills relevant for future employments, enhancing their networks and contributing to personal dignity. Assistance will also be provided to access digital financial services and insurance schemes. The idea is that their increased income combined with life and employability skills and enhance self-esteem will help beneficiaries invest productively to ensure a stream of income in years to come. Moreover, the capacity of the local government to implement pro-poor, gender-sensitive social-transfer projects will be enhanced.

The overall objective of SWAPNO-II is to lift some of the poorest women, living in areas most vulnerable to natural hazards, out of poverty and help them sustain higher income levels after the project period. More specifically, the project aims to: - Increase the income and assets the target women have, - Enhance the human capabilities of these women for exercising choices, - Strengthen their resilience to shocks, including those created by natural disasters and climate change, - Enhance the financial inclusion to provide these women with more equitable opportunities, and - Improve policies and mechanisms for sustaining the benefits of this project and broaden its reach. SWAPNO-II will make different contributions to the women included in the different phases. For those who have already been employed in SWAPNO-I, this new phase will contribute with some additional learning, a few activities and follow-up to ensure that the benefits are sustainable. However, for the 3600 new beneficiaries, SWAPNO-II is intended to provide all of the above-mentioned results.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

SWAPNO-II syftar till att öka målgruppens inkomster och tillgångar genom att vidga deras valmöjligheter, öka deras kapacitet att göra val, stärka deras motståndskraft mot externa chocker, inklusive klimatrelaterade katastrofer och öka deras tillgång till finansiella tjänster samt se till att projektets fördelar kvarstår över tid.
Målen ska nås genom en kombination av ansträngningar. Kvinnorna anställs först i offentliga arbeten fora att återuppbygga eller klimatsäkra kritisk infrastruktur och för det arbetet får det en liten, men säker lön var fjortonde dag under ett halvår. En del av lönen sparas automatiskt och den delen får kvinnorna tillgång till som en större engångssumma vid anställningsperiodens slut. Meningen är att den ska möjliggöra för kvinnorna att starta sina egna småföretag. Kvinnorna får också utbildning i olika vardagskunskaper och lite yrkeskunskaper som är relevanta för att hitta anställning eller starta eget företag vilket ökar deras nätverk och personliga värdighet. Stöd ges också för tillgång till digitala finansiella tjänster och försäkringar. Idén är att kvinnornas ökade inkomster, kombinerat med ökade kunskaper och självsäkerhet ska hjälpa dem att investera på ett produktivt sätt som ger dem avkastning under kommande år. Dessutom bidar projektet till att öka de lokala myndigheternas kapacitet att implementera fattigdomsreducerande och genderkänsliga sociala transfereringssystem.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This project aims at sustainably lifting some of Bangladesh’s poorest women, living in rural areas prone to the negative effects of climate change, of out of extreme poverty, primarily by making use of productive income-generating opportunities. The main beneficiaries are 3600 women in the districts of Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha and Jamalpur even if a substantially larger number of people, including these women’s children, will benefit, to various extents, from the positive effects of this project.
SWAPNO-II aims to increase the targeted women’s income and assets by expanding their choices, enhance their capabilities for exercising choices, strengthen their resilience to shocks, including disasters and climate change, and enhance their financial inclusion and ensure that the benefits are sustainable over time.
This will be achieved through a combination of efforts. The women will first be engaged in public-works to rehabilitate and/or climate proof critical local infrastructure for which they receive a small, predictable, fortnightly, salary during a period of six months. A part of the remuneration is set aside in compulsory savings which the women will access as a lump-sum at the end of the public-works period to allow them to, for example start their own small-scale businesses. They will also be trained in various life-skills as well as skills relevant for future employments, enhancing their networks and contributing to personal dignity. Assistance will also be provided to access digital financial services and insurance schemes. The idea is that their increased income combined with life and employability skills and enhance self-esteem will help beneficiaries invest productively to ensure a stream of income in years to come. Moreover, the capacity of the local government to implement pro-poor, gender-sensitive social-transfer projects will be enhanced.

The overall objective of SWAPNO-II is to lift some of the poorest women, living in areas most vulnerable to natural hazards, out of poverty and help them sustain higher income levels after the project period. More specifically, the project aims to: - Increase the income and assets the target women have, - Enhance the human capabilities of these women for exercising choices, - Strengthen their resilience to shocks, including those created by natural disasters and climate change, - Enhance the financial inclusion to provide these women with more equitable opportunities, and - Improve policies and mechanisms for sustaining the benefits of this project and broaden its reach. SWAPNO-II will make different contributions to the women included in the different phases. For those who have already been employed in SWAPNO-I, this new phase will contribute with some additional learning, a few activities and follow-up to ensure that the benefits are sustainable. However, for the 3600 new beneficiaries, SWAPNO-II is intended to provide all of the above-mentioned results.

Det långsiktiga utvecklingsmålet är allmän tillgång till säkert och hållbart dricksvatten. De förväntade resultaten av projektet är:
1. År 2020 ska roller och ansvar för reglering, kapacitetsuppbyggnad, tillhandahållande av tjänster och provning av vattenkvalitet vara tilldelade. 2. År 2020 är harmoniserade system och metoder utplacerade av ansvariga aktörer för leverans av arseniksäkert och bakteriologiskt säkert dricksvatten. 3. År 2020 används evidensbaserade system av ansvariga aktörer inom delsektorerna hälsa och dricksvatten.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The intervention is considered to deliver sustainable results that contributes to the Results strategy for Bangladesh has made significant progress in increasing access to improved drinking water in both urban and rural areas, and to all segments of the population. As a result of this, Bangladesh achieved the Millennium Development Goal 7c related to drinking water well before the end date in 2015 and currently 98% of the population enjoys access to a protected drinking water source (JMP, 2015). However, looking past the quality proxy of “improved water source” reveals that the water supply is undermined by quality issues and unreliable service provision (MICS 2009). According to the most recent Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, MICS, only 35 % of households consume water which meets the Bangladesh standard for both arsenic and bacteriological contamination. WHO estimate that chronic arsenic exposure leads to 43 000 deaths annually having a significant economic impact on the country. Despite improvements in prevention and treatment of waterborne disease, 15% of post-neonatal deaths all 6% of all U5 deaths are currently due to diarrhea.
Arsenic contamination of shallow wells has been a recognized problem since the 1990s but, despite large investments by donors and government, the result has only been a decrease in exposure of 1%, which actually translates into an increased number of affected people given the population growth during the same period. Several factors contribute to this limited success and water quality issues in general, but at the core lay weak regulation and accountability, poor information management, and a lack of capacity of government to coordinate and engage with small scale entrepreneurs in the water sector.
The proposed programme will support the government of Bangladesh to lead, coordinate and facilitate the implementation and management of water safety frameworks and protocols. The long term development goal is universal access to safe and sustainable drinking water and the expected outcomes of the project are: 1. By 2020, roles and responsibilities for regulation, capacity building, service provision and water quality testing are assigned. 2. By 2020, harmonized systems and procedures are deployed by stakeholders for the delivery of arsenic and bacteriologically safe drinking water. 3. By 2020, evidence-based systems are used by accountable stakeholders in the health and drinking water sub-sectors.

The key outcomes and outputs of the project are: 1. By 2020, roles and responsibilities for regulation, capacity building, service provision and water quality testing are assigned 1.1 A government-led platform for adaptation and adoption of sub-sector wide scalable water safety models and protocols is established and functional 1.2 Drinking water safety policies and regulations are complied with and capacity of public/ private personnel developed to deliver safe water at-scale ' 2. By 2020, harmonized systems and procedures are deployed by stakeholders for the delivery of arsenic and bacteriologically safe drinking water 2.1 A government-led national performance-based monitoring and surveillance system for urban and rural drinking water safety is established and functional ' 2.2 A harmonized National Arsenic Mitigation Protocol and evidence-based model is adopted and implemented securing safe water rights 3. By 2020, evidence-based systems are used by accountable stakeholders in the health and drinking water sub-sectors 3.1 Arsenicosis case detection and management protocol is operationalized & evidence and database of arsenicosis patients established and strengthened 3.2 The integrated WASH National Monitoring and Evaluation System is established, populated and functional 4. By 2020, Rohingya and Host Communities in Ukhiya and Teknaf Upazilas under Cox’s Bazar District have sustainable WASH services 4.1 The Behaviour of both host and Rohingya communities have been changed through safe sanitation and hygiene intervention change and safe sanitation 4.2 Rohingya and Host communities are trained on Water Safety Plan (WSP) and able to ensure their own access to safe water 4.3 GoB departments and stakeholders are strengthened to ensure sustainable WASH services for the target communities.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

description.narrative: This is the conclusion on performance of the contribution for the period October 2019 to September 2020. During this period the contribution progress was satisfactory, though during March - May 2020 field activities were disrupted/slowed down due to Covid 19 pandemic. Key achievements during the period: -Strengthening of the Policy Support Branch (PSB), which is now actively implementing a one-year action plan developed as part of the Sida project. Activities that have been initiated by the PSB include the revision of the Sector Development Plan (SDP) 2011-2025 and the National Policy for Water Supply and Sanitation 1998 as well as the development of the National Operation and Maintenance Strategy for Water Supply and Sanitation. -Implementing partners have been engaged for field mobilization, pro-poor site selection, water safety planning, sanitation and hygiene promotion. -Completion of the WASH Bottleneck Analysis workshops in the remaining five divisions making a total of eight. The information generated through this bottom-up consultative process will be utilized for a joint sector review and integrated national Ställningstagande till rapport Statement on report Contribution ID: 52170040 2 (3) action planning. -Finalization of the water quality component of the National Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), which provides the most current source of nationally representative water quality information and benchmarks the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) of water national indicators. -National WASH in Health Care Facilities (HCF) Strategy developed and approved. -National Implementation Plan on Arsenic Mitigation disseminated, and stakeholders sensitized. -WASH and Arsenicosis Technical Committee established to strengthen monitoring and reporting systems between WASH and Health sectors. -During this reporting period, 126,750 women, men and children gained access to arsenic-safe drinking water from 462 new water supply facilities and 355 rehabilitations of existing water facilities. Cumulatively, a total of 130,150 women, men and children gained access to arsenic-safe drinking water from a total of 498 new and 355 rehabilitated water points. This represents 41% of the total target beneficiaries of 316,000 people (including Cox’s Bazar- Rohingya Response). From March 2020 on wards Unicef is a leading partner of the Government of Bangladesh in addressing\responding to Covid 19 pandemic and related issues. They are playing vital role in framing policies and guidelines along with the Health Department and Department of Public Health and Engineering and other partners. Unicef also providing awareness and other support to the community and local government through their programms. Progress of activities also reported for Cox\s Bazar component. Some of the activities there were no progress, or are not clear. -No progress reported in Wash in educational facilities. -No progress also in the area linked to open defecation in Camps and host communities The reason they mentioned is restricted field movement due to Covid 19, but they got about 6 months time before Covid starts. The issues will be discussed with UNICEF. - Regarding UNICEFs role in humanitarian coordination in Wash sector in Cox\s Bazar needs also to discuss further in a suitable time. - The issue of continuing distribution of soap, jerrican and water tablets will also be discussed, since these are humanitarian nature of activity.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Regional Community Forestry Training Centre for Asia and the Pacific (RECOFTC) har inkommit med en ansökan till Utvecklingssektionen vid ambassaden i Bangkok om kärnstöd gällande totalt SEK 60 miljoner för femårsperioden 1 oktober 2016- 30 september 2021 vilket är en fortsättning på Sidas kärnstöd till organisationen under 2010-2015. Insatsen syftar till att stärka och tydliggöra människor rättigheter relaterat till den skog de brukar samt stärka en öppen, rättvis och hållbar förvaltning av skogen där människor beroende av den för sitt uppehälle står i centrum. Särskilt fokus ligger på kvinnors och ursprungsbefolkningars rättigheter. Implementeringen följer organisationens strategi ”People and Forests for a Greener Future” 2013-2018 Stödet förväntas bidra till fyra resultat: 1) Institutioner och resurser arbetar effektivare för att säkerställa möjligheter till Community Forestry. 2) Institutioner arbetar aktivt med att förbättra lokala näringsmöjligheter med hållbara Community Forestry-metoder.3) Stärkta möjligheter för delaktighet i hanteringen av klimatförändringar för människor beroende av skogen för sitt uppehälle. 4) Institutioner för att hantera konflikter rörande naturresurser är på plats och arbetar effektivare. Sverige stöd kommer att bidra med 10% av RECOFTC’s totala budget och 28% av dess kärnstöd. Organisationens portfölj inbegriper även 72% projektstöd från olika finansiärer.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Regional Community Forestry Training Center for Asia and the Pacific (RECOFTC) has submitted an application to the Development Cooperation Section at the Embassy of Sweden in Bangkok for core support of a total of SEK 60 million for the five-year period 1 October 2016- 30 September 2021. The core support is a continuation of Sida's core support to the organization during 2010-2015. The initiative aims to strengthen and clarify people’s rights related to the forest they manage and strengthen an open, equitable and sustainable management of the forest with people depend on it for their livelihoods are at the center. Special focus is on women’s and local people’s rights.The implementation follows the organization’s strategy "People and Forests for a Greener Future" 2013-2018. The support is expected to contribute to four results: 1. Institutions and resources for securing community forestry are more effective. 2) Institutions are actively enhancing local livelihoods and sustainable CF practices.3) Enabling conditions for local people’s engagement in forested landscapes in the context of climate change are strengthened. 4) Institutions to transform conflict are in place and increasingly effective. The Swedish support will contribute with 10% of RECOFTC's total budget and 28% of its core support. The organization's portfolio includes 72% project funding from various donors.

description.narrative: Some highlights of the results during October 2019 to September 2020 are: RECOFTC launched an annual report "Building resilience through community forestry" from October 2017 to September 2019. It shows the progress made by forest communities over the past two years. There are nine stories shared in the report demonstrate that RECOFTC is prepared to meet challenges. For instance: i) RECOFTC’s alumni were inspired to use community forestry as the entry point for making significant changes in the policies, forests and lives of forest communities in their home countries; ii) and young journalists reporting on forest issues, gender champions reshaping the forest sector and forest communities and user groups forming their own influential associations to attain their aspirations. RECOFTC also launched an open e-course on the Community Forestry 101. The free e-course introduces community forestry as a pathway to solving the world’s greatest social and environmental challenges. The report on "Civil society increasingly shapes forest laws in the Mekong region" was published, as part of the Voices for Mekong Forests (V4MF), an EU-funded project to strengthen the participation of non-state actors in forest governance across the Mekong region. This special report highlights how five countries in the Mekong are opening up decision-making processes to civil society as they reform policies and laws governing forests. It explores why civic engagement matters, how it is happening, what challenges prevent more effective participation and how to overcome them. It highlights stories from Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Thailand and Vietnam. RECOFTC and FAO conducted a research from June to July 2020 in the early phase of the pandemic and lockdowns in seven Asian countries: Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Nepal, Thailand and Vietnam. Through interviews with 435 people, RECOFTC and FAO aimed to learn how forest communities dealt with COVID-19 and lockdowns. The findings are, for example: eighty percent of respondents said the lockdown harmed their livelihoods or food security; half reported being unable to sell their forest products because of travel restrictions, a lack of buyers or depressed prices that made trading unprofitable. The findings will enable RECOFTC and FAO to recommend policies and interventions to strengthen community forestry as a social and economic safety net. Through its flagship, Weaving Leadership for Gender Equality initiative (WAVES) program, it has built a network of 31 gender leaders who are influencing gender equality in climate change, REDD+ and forestry, law enforcement, governance and trade policies and processes in seven countries of the Asia-Pacific region. In relation to this, a brown-bag lunch was organized for Embassy staff to learn more about WAVES program. In addition, RECOFTC is finalizing its integrated gender action plan to drive consistent and impact-driven programming of gender equality across all of its Strategic Goals and interventions.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNDPs regionala enhet i Bangkok har ansökt om stöd från Sida uppgående till 90 000 000 SEK för genomförande av programmet "Strengthening the Governance of Climate Change Finance to Enhance Gender Equality" (Förbättrad styrning/genomförande av klimat-finansiering för förbättrad jämställdhet) under perioden 2017-2019. Länderna som berörs är Bangladesh, Indonesien, Kambodja, Thailand, Tonga och Vanuatu. Länderna kommer att samverka och utbyta erfarenheter genom programmet och de regionala organisationerna Pacific Island Forum (PIF) och Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) kommer att stärkas.
Programmet bygger på en tidigare fas finansierad av Sverige. Programmets syfte är att stärka ländernas kapacitet att genomföra nationell och lokal budgetreform, inklusive att söka internationell klimatfinansiering, samt uveckla planeringsprocesser för att systematiskt integrera effekterna av klimatförändringar i offentliga investeringar. Även jämställdhetsaspekter integreras för positiva effekter för fattigdomsminskning och mänskliga rättigheter. Mer information om programmet finns på https://www.climatefinance-developmenteffectiveness.org/.
Det övergripande målet är "En ökning av antalet offentliga investeringar som adresserar klimatförändringar och samtidigt främjar jämställdhet, mänskliga rättigheter och fattigdomsminskning."
Resultat som förväntas uppnås är: - Budgetprocesser som i ökande grad innehåller klimatinvesteringar som är jämställdhetsorienterade med positiva resultat för fattigdomsminskning och mänskliga rättigheter. - Ansvarsutkrävande för klimatrelaterade investeringar som integrerar jämställdhet vilka har positiva resultat för fattigdomsminskning och mänskliga rättigheter. - Regionala institutioner har förstärkt roll i ett integrerat arbetssätt för mer jämställdhetsorienterad klimatbudgetering med positiva resultat för fattigdoms minskning och mänskliga rättigheter. - Internationella policyprocesser ger högre prioritet för nationella budgetsystem som levererar mer jämställdhetsorienterade klimatinvesteringar vilka bidrar till positiva resultat för fattigdomsminskning och mänskliga rättigheter.
Under beredningen har en intensiv dialog mellan ambassaden och UNDP förts som bland annat resulterat i en bättre integrering av jämställdhet och mänskliga rättigheter i programmet samt utökat samarbete med UN Women och civilsamhället. UNDP har besvarat ambassadens frågor i två matriser som bifogas beslutet. Svaren har också integrerats i beredningstexten.
Sverige är tillsvidare ensam finansiär av programmet vilket bedöms vara tillräckligt för genomförandet. DFID finansierar ett parallellt program i Sydasien. Ingen vidareförmedling av medel kommer att ske. De organisationer som ges uppdrag ersätts efter slutfört arbete.
Programmet startar med en inledande fas på 6-månader då programdokument, resultatramverk, mm kommer att finslipas. Efter fyra månader av den inledande perioden ska UNDP till ambassaden inkomma med ett rapportutkast. Detta utgör en möjlighet för ambassaden att kommentera och påverka rapportens innehåll. Ambassaden ska godkänna rapporten vid 6-månaders periodens slut. Ytterligar åtgärder kan krävas av ambassaden om så är motiverat. En separat utbetalning kommer att göras för inception perioden.
Rätten för ambassaden att godkänna resultaten från den inledande perioden är inte reglerad i avtalet. Den avtalsmall som fastställts mellan Sverige och UNDP kan endast justeras på centralnivå. Ambassaden har vidtagit de riskreducreande åtgärder som mallen tillåter, att dela upp utbetalningarna för 2017 en innan inledande perioden och en efter. Då det i avtalsmallen finns utrymme för att justera utbetalningsplan utifrån projektets utveckling finns en rätt att ändra utbetalningsplan för det fall att förväntningarna på inledande perioden inte infrias. Härutöver finns en rätt för parterna att säga upp avtalet med en månads uppsägningstid.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNDP Bangkok Regional Hub has applied for support from Sida amounting to 90 000 000 SEK for the implementation of the regional program "Strengthening the Governance of Climate Change Finance to Enhance gender Equality". The countries that will be covered are Bangladesh, Cambodia, Indonesia, Thailand, and Tonga, Vanuatu in the Pacific, during the period 2017-2021
The programme builds on a previous phase supported by Sweden and aims to strengthen the capacity of the governments to implement their national and local budgeting reform and planning process to be able to systematically address climate change in their public investments in an integrated manner, and address gender equality, human rights and poverty. More details of the programme can be found at https://www.climatefinance-developmenteffectiveness.org/.
The objective is: To increase in the number of public investments that respond to climate change whilst also promoting gender equality, human rights and poverty reduction.
The planned results are: (a) Budget processes increasingly formulate climate change related investments that are gender responsive and have positive impacts on poverty and human rights. b) Accountability for gender-responsive climate change related investments that have impacts on poverty and human rights is enhanced. c) Regional institutions increasingly play a role in the integrated approach to gender-responsive climate change budgeting that have impacts on poverty and human rights. d) International policy processes give increasing priority to strengthen domestic budget systems that enable delivery of gender responsive climate change investments that have positive impacts on poverty and human rights.
During the assessment, there has been an intense dialogue between the Embassy and UNDP which, among other things, has resulted in better integration of gender equality and human rights in the program, as well as increased cooperation with UN Women and civil society. UNDP has responded to the Embassy issues in two "responses matrixes" attached to the decision. The responses have also been integrated into the text in the assessment.
Sweden is the sole financier of the programme. Co-financing with other financiers will be further investigated. Forwarding of funds to other organisations will not be done. Assigned organisations will be paid after completion of work.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Oxfam Novib har ansökt om stöd från Sida uppgående till 105 234 986 SEK för genomförande av det regionala programmet "Förbättrad regional gränsöverskridande vattenresursförvaltning" i sydasien, under perioden 2016-2022.
Programmet kommer att bidra till att sårbara människor i tre flodområden i sydasien får bättre tillgång till och kontroll över gränsöverskridande vattenresurser. De tre identifierade floder områdena är Makahali/Sharda i Nepal och Indien, Bramaputra/Megna i Indien och Bangladesh samt Salween i Myanmar. Programmet har potential för att nå miljontals utsatta människor direkt och indirekt. Planerade resultat är:
-Förbättrade policyer och metoder för myndigheter som bidrar till att skydda rättigheter avseende vattenresurser för utsatta kommuner i flodnära områden.
-Förbättrade policyer och metoder för företag och andra aktörer som respekterar rättigheter avseende vattenresurser för utsatta kommuner i flodnära områden.
- Stärkt kapacitet för utsatta grupper i flodnära områden och CSO för att påverka gräns-överskridande vattenresursförvaltning.
-Ett fjärde resultat integreras på tvären i programmet och avser stärkande av kvinnors profil och påverkansmöjligheter i dialog och beslutsprocesser avseende vatten resurs förvaltning och infrastruktur.
Sverige är ensam finansiär av programmet vilket bedöms vara rimligt för genomförandet. Ytterligare finansiärer kan bidra till högre stabilitet varvid andra finansierings möjligheter kommer att undersökas under inception perioden. Oxfam Novib behåller 2% av budgeten och 43 % har avsatts för Oxfams landkontor i Indien, Nepal, Bangladesh, Myanmar och Cambodia. Landkontoren vidareförmedlar därutöver 55% av budgeten till ett antal internationella/regionala organisationer och till lokala organisationer i fyra länder (ej i Kambodja). Oxfam Novib skall i en årlig revision summera resultaten av revisioner från de fem landskontoren, inklusive viktiga resultat från revisioner av lokala och regionala NGO:er som är tredjepartsmottagare av medel.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Oxfam Novib has applied for support from Sida amounting to 105 234 986 SEK for the implementation of the regional program "Improving regional cross-border water resource management" in South Asia (India, Bangladesh, Nepal and Myanmar) during the period 2016-2022.
The program will help vulnerable people in the three river basins in South Asia to gain better access to and control of trans-boundary water resources. The planned results are:
- Improved policies and practices of governments that protect the rights of river basin communities to water resources.
- Improved policies and practice of private sector and other actors that respect the right to river basin communities to water resources.
- Strengthened capacity of river basin communities and civil society to influence trans-boundary water resource management.
A fourth result is mainstreamed in the program and intends to strengthen women's profile and influence in the dialogue and decision-making related to water resource management and infrastructure.
Sweden is the sole financier of the program, but additional funding is possible and will be further looked into during the inception phase. Approximately 55% of the budget will be paid to a number of international/regional organizations, and through Oxfam's country offices in the four countries which will forward funds to local organizations.
The program will help vulnerable people in the three river basins in South Asia to gain better access to and better control of transboundary vattenreurser. The planned results are:
- Improved policies and practices for agencies that help to protect the rights to water for vulnerable communities in the riverine areas.
- Improved policies and practices for companies and other actors which respect the rights to water for vulnerable communities in the riverine areas.

description.narrative: Oxfam assess that the program's overall progress is on track. Out of the five outcomes, one is delayed (number two) but the others are on track. Spending year 2 is 69% compared to the budget. These are some examples of results the program has acheived so far, according to the annual report; 1) - Development of sustainable sand mining framework in Mahakali river. - Political Economy Analysis of Transboundary Water Cooperation in Mahakali - Sharda Basin to inform transboundary decision-making processes. - Renewable energt exchange between government and civil society actors from India, Nepal and Myanmar. - Strengthened government participation in the Meghna basin. 2) - Building greater understanding of the private sector's role in renewable energy. - Engaging sand mining and fishing contractors along the Mahakali basin. 3) - National Energy Forum in Myanmar arranged November 2018. - Joint research strategy for academia and CSOs in the Meghna basin developed with involvement of 8 organisations. The outcome will be shared at the Meghna Knowledge Forum in 2020. - The Salween Watch, a collective of CSOs and advocacy networks working in the Salween basin, sharing updates and seeking to influence hydropower policies. 4) - River Governance Curriculum being developed including various aspects of water governance. - Communities' fishing rights recognized in Daw Lar lake. - Communities have access to flood information through Early Warning Systems in 30 villages in the Sharada river basin. 5) - First International Women and Rivers Congress arranged in March 2019 bringing together researchers, practiioners and journalists representing 32 countries. Road map and action plan produced. - Women Water User Groups in Mahakali and Brahmaputra basins engage with an electricity company and a sugar mill on issues related to water contamination and risk management. A Mid-Term Evaluation was conducted from April - June 2019, covering the period January 2017 to December 2018. Oxfam has prepared a Management Response to the MTE.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 ICIMOD har ansökt om stöd från Sida uppgående till 150 MSEK för genomförande av ICIMOD:s program i regionen Hindu Kush Himalaya enligt planen "Medium Term Action Plan, 2018-2022". ICIMOD är en mellanstatlig organisation som genom regionalt samarbete utvecklar och delar kunskap för att främja hållbar utveckling i regionen. Organisationens medlemsländer är Afganistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Kina, Indien, Myanmar, Nepal och Pakistan. ICIMOD:s program bidrar till minskad fattigdom, minskad fysisk och social sårbarhet samt förbättring av ekosysemtjänster för män, kvinnor och barn i regionen. Det svenska bidraget ges som ett programstöd i syfte att harmoniera stödet så långt möjligt för ett effektivt genomförande av femårsplanen. Programstödet innefattar stöd till regionala program, innovation och integration samt till institutionella funktioner. Det svenska stödet samfinansieras med andra givare.
Planerade strategiska resultat är: - Spridning av innovationer och praxis som utvecklats av ICIMOD och partners för anpassning till förändringar som leder till positiva resultat för män, kvinnor och barn. T ex översvämningsvarningssystem och klimatanpassade värdekedjor. - Betydande framsteg i generering och användning av relevant data, kunskap och analys. T ex mäta, bevaka och hantera luftföroreningsnivåer. - Betydande framsteg i tillvägagångssätt och kunskap som stödjer jämställdhet och inkluderande utveckling. T ex stärka kvinnors kapacitet och ledarskapsroller inom jordbruk och lokala beslutsfattande institutioner. - Betydande framsteg i mänsklig- och institutionell kapacitet. T ex stärka medlemsländernas miljöförvaltning. - Betydligt påverkade policyer genom ICIMOD och partnerorganisationers arbete. T ex bidra till förbättrad miljölagstiftning i regionen. - Förstärkt regionalt samarbete relaterat till hållbar utveckling i bergsområden. T ex främja tekniskt kunskapsutbyte mellan länder och gemensam förvaltning av gränsöverskridande naturresurser. - Global kännedom om det aktuella bergsområdets (Hindu Kush Himalaya) betydelse för förbättrade och resilienta livsvillkor och ekosystem. T ex få genomslag i de globala klimatförhandlingarna.
Det svenska bidraget ska finansiera slutförande av den pågående fasen under 2017 samt ett brett programstöd för ICIMOD:s femårsplan 2018-2022. Finansiering av den nya femårsplanen planeras ske med stöd från 8 givare där Sverige ingår. Dessutom kommer mindre belopp att tillhandahållas från de åtta medlemsländerna. ICIMOD behåller ca 70 % av budgeten för de regionala programmen och vidareförmedlar ca 30 % till partnerorganisationer. Sverige har samarbetat med ICIMOD under lång tid och har under perioden 2012-2016 finansierat två av ICIMOD:s initiativ: Atmosfärinitiativet samt klimatanpassningsinitiativet HICAP.
ICIMOD ska enligt enligt föreslagna avtalsvillkor inkomma med årlig revision av tredje parts organisationer som får medel överstigande 505 000 SEK. Avtalsutkast har tagits fram i nära samarbete med JUR.
Det miljöekonomiska forskningsnätverket SANDEE, som under 15 år med goda resultat stötts genom Sveriges Strategi för Forskningssamarbete, integreras från 2017 med ICIMOD och får härefter del av programstödet till organisationen. På så sätt kan synergier mellan forskning och regional utvecklingssamarbete nyttjas. Resultat kan även fortsättningsvis rapporteras på och bidra till Forskningsstrategin.
Vid sidan om, men kopplat till detta stöd, kommer Sverige också att finansiera en Biträdande Bilateral Expert (BBE) till ICIMOD, inom området vatten och klimatanpassning.
Beredningen är skriven på engelska eftersom nationell handläggare bidragit i beredningarbetet och kommer att delta i uppföljning av insatsen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 ICIMOD has applied for support from Sida amounting to 150 000 000 SEK for implementation of ICIMOD's operations in the Hindu Kush Himalayan region, according to the plan "Medium Term Action Plan, 2018-2022". ICIMOD is an intergovernmental organization which through regional cooperation generates and shares knowledge to promote sustainble development in the region. The organization's member countries are Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, China, India, Myanmar, Nepal and Pakistan. The ICIMOD's programs contribute to reduced poverty, reduced physical and social vulnerability and improvement of ecosystem services for men, women and children in the region. The Swedish contribution is given as overall program support in order to harmonize the support as far as possible for the effective implementation of the five-year plan. Program support includes support for regional programs, - innovation and integration as well as institutional functions.
Planned strategic results are: - Dissemination of innovations and practices developed by ICIMOD and partners for adaptation to changes that result in positive results for men, women and children. E.g.: flood early warning systems and climate change adapted value chains. - Significant progress in the generation and use of relevant data, knowledge and analysis. E.g.: Measure, monitor and manage air pollution levels. - Significant progress in approaches and knowledge supporting gender equality and inclusive development. E.g.: Strengthen women's capacity and leadership roles in agriculture and local decision making bodies. - Significant progress in human and institutional capacity. E.g.: Strengthen the member countries' environmental management authorities. - Significantly affected policies through ICIMOD and partner organizations work. E.g.: contribute to improved environmental legislation in the region. - Strengthened regional cooperation related to sustainable development in mountain areas. E.g.: promote technical exchange between countries and joint management of transboundary natural resources. - Global awareness of the importance of mountain areas for improved and resilient living conditions and ecosystems. E.g.: influence at the global climate negotiations.
The Swedish contribution will fund the completion of the current phase in 2017 and a broad program support for ICIMOD's five-year plan 2018-2022. Funding of the new five-year plan is planned with support from 8 donors where Sweden is included. In addition, smaller amounts will be provided from the eight member states. ICIMOD retains approximately 70% of the budget for regional programs and transmits about 30% to partner organizations. Sweden is a longstanding cooperation partner of ICIMOD, and Sweden has during the period 2012-2016 financed two of ICIMOD's initiatives, the climate change adaptation initiative HICAP and the Atmosphere initiative.
ICIMOD performs annual audits of third party organizations that receive funds exceeding SEK 505,000.
The environmental economics network SANDEE, which has for 15 years been supported with good results under Sweden's Strategy for Research Cooperation, will from 2017 be integrated into ICIMOD and take part of Sweden's new programme support to ICIMOD. SANDEE's results will continue to contribute to the Research Strategy.
Sweden will also separately finance a Bilateral Associate Expert (BAE) position at ICIMOD, in the field of water and climate adaptation.

description.narrative: One of the issues that ICIMOD has focused on during 2019 is communicating the key findings of the HKH Assessment Report and ensuring government validation of the HKH Call to Action as a roadmap for the future of the HKH region. The HKH Assessment was publicly launched in February and it has been downloaded 491 000 times. The interest and media coverage has been huge, also in Sweden. The assessment has - inter alia - resulted in; - Increased ownership of the HKH Call to Action by the HKH countries,- Strengthened partnership and alliance for regional action and sustainable mountain development among the HKH countries,- Promotion of the mountain agenda through the HKH Call to Action in global forums. Other examples of results achieved during 2019 include the following; - Together with partners, climate-smart practices and technologies and nature based solutions have been designed, tested and scaled-up. For example; climate resilient agriculture and springshed revival in Bhutan, launch of a national programme in Nepal on Climate Smart Villages based on an ICIMOD pilot programme, implementation of Community Based Early Warning Systems in Pakistan and in Nepal In Pakistan, more than 1000 brick kilns have been converted to the more environmental friendly zig-zag technology and the construction of traditional brick kilns has been banned. - The HKH assessment roll out was the key priority in the area of generation and use of relevant data, knowledge and analysis. Findings have been presented extensively in national, regional and global forums, for example the World Economic Forum and the former Prime Minister of Bhutan focused the assessment in his Ted Talk "An urgent call to protect the world's Third Pole". - Gender integration across regional programmes, and within ICIMOD, continues to be given priority. During 2019, a policy on Prevention and Redressal of Sexual Harassment in the Work Place was developed and approved. Female professionals as lead authors in major scientific papers are being promoted and in 2019 a female author contributed in 48% of the publications published. - Human and institutional capacity of partners and have been developed at a large scale and throughout the HKH region. - Policies that have been influenced by ICIMOD and its partners include the Forest Act in Nepal and the section on payment for environmental services, inclusion of management of biodiversity across borders in the draft Forest Policy in India and directions for organic farming, health of mountain ecosystems and land use in Pakistan. Another example is the inclusion of transboundary collaboration for conservation by the government of Yunnan. - Key highlights of enhanced regional cooperation include the Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Capability initiative bringing together renewable energy experts from across the region and management of water resources in the Upper Indus Basin. - The HKH Assessment is one example of how ICIMOD has succeeded in achieving global recognition of the importance of mountains. They arranged well attended events at the UNFCC COP-25, co-hosted an IPCC Working Group Lead Author Meeting in Kathmandu and contributed to the Global Biodiversity Report. When it comes to the administrative/internal control follow-up of Sida's support to ICIMOD, the PO and Controller visited the organisation in Kathmandu in March 2019. Meetings took place with ICIMOD staff, as well as the chair (Australia) and co-chair (Norway) of the Development Partner Group to discuss programmatic and administrative issues. One result of these meetings is the development and agreement on a format of the annual financial reporting acceptable to donors and ICIMOD. An amendment to the agreement between Sida and ICIMOD confirmed this change. During 2019, ICIMOD received additional Sida funding of 10 MSEK for 2019 for work related to climate change mitigation. The annual meeting of ICIMOD took place in September, 2019, in Sikkim. In addition to the meetings, also field trips were arranged and as well as meetings with ICIMOD partners. Sida representatives, both from Bangkok and Stockholm, participated and it was a very useful and well arranged event. ICIMOD has been involved in, and contributed to, the planning for a possible Sida guarantee to a Swedish Bank, the Himalaya Guarantee Fund. ICIMOD has a very good reputation and this is confirmed in different ways. One of them is the great interest of becoming a Independent Board Member. This year, two new members are to be selected and 11 highly qualified persons applied. The selection was more difficult than earlier years,
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

The support is in form of core support to the MRC basket fund for the period 2016-2020 and supports the implementation of the MRC's Strategic Plan.

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This project is a joint collaboration between UN Women and UN Environment, which aims to contribute to the overall outcome of 'Implementation of climate-change and DRR actions in Asia and the Pacific address key drivers of gender- based vulnerabilities and enhance human rights'. The project is implemented in Bangladesh, Cambodia and Vietnam and has also a regional and Asia and Pacific focus.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UN Women har tillsammans med UN Environment ansökt om 79 100 000 kronor för att genomföra projektet "Strengthening Human Rights and Gender Equality Through Climate Change Action and Disaster Risk Reduction". Projektet syftar till att bidra till det övergripande målet att "Klimat- och katastrof- åtgärder i Asien och Stillahavsområdet integrerar jämställdhet och mänskliga rättigheter". Projektet genomförs i Bangladesh, Kambodja och Vietnam men har också ett regionalt fokus på Asien och Oceanien.
Under det övergripande målet planeras verksamhet som bidrar till fem resultatområden: 1) Ökat åtnjutande av grundläggande rättigheter för kvinnor samt ökat politiskt deltagande särskilt i beslutsfattande inom miljö/klimat- och katastrofåtgärder, 2) Beslutsfattare och nyckelaktörer inom området miljö/klimat- och katastrofåtgärder har förbättrad tillgång till samt förmåga att använda sig av köns- och åldersuppdelad data 3) Nationella lagar och policyer samt beslut kring klimatfinansiering integrerar och stärker mänskliga rättigheter och jämställdhet, 4) Förbättrade livsvillkor för kvinnor genom ökad tillgång till resurser som förnybar energi, 5) Ökad integrering av mänskliga rättigheter och jämställdhet inom regionala normativa processer inom miljö/klimat- och katastrofåtgärder.
Insatsen ska genomföras gemensamt av UN Women och UN Environment med UN Women som avtalspart till ambassaden och huvudsakligt ansvarig genomförare. De huvudsakliga aktiviteterna inom insatsen utgörs av bl.a. 1) kapacitetsutbildning kring jämställdhet för civila samhällsorganisationer, tjänstemän inom huvudministerier och statliga och mellanstatliga institut och övriga nyckelaktör som arbetar inom områdena miljö/klimat- och katastrofåtgärder, 2) utveckling av metoder och verktyg för förbättrad data-insamling kring jämställdhet, 3) studier och kartläggningar av existerande policyer och lagar inom miljö/klimat- och katastrofåtgärder, 4) genomförande av lokala studier kring användningen av förnybar energi samt utveckling av finansiella instrument för ökad tillgång och användning av förnybar energi för kvinnor på landsbygden.
Insatsen innebär ett nytt sätt att samarbeta för UN Women och UN Environment som tillsammans och på integrerat sätt kommer att arbeta för ett ökat genomslag av mänskliga rättigheter och jämställdhet inom miljö/klimat och vice versa. Projektet ses som innovativt och strategiskt för genomförande av ett integrerat och holistiskt sätt att arbeta med mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och miljö/klimat i Asien och Oceanien. UN Women och UN Environment med sina respektive mandat är nyckelaktörer i FN:s utvecklingssamarbete inom områdena miljö/klimat och jämställdhet. Denna insats kan således även tänkas bidra till ett ökat genomslag av integrering av frågorna inom respektive organs och FNs övriga miljö- och jämställdhetsarbete vilket i sin tur kan bidra till ökad integrering av frågorna på bredare front.
